TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed IPStatus extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Reports the status of sending an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo message to a computer.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping> class uses the values in this enumeration to set the <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.PingReply.Status%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property. The <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping> class returns <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.PingReply> objects when you call the <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.Send%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.SendAsync%2A?displayProperty=fullName> methods to check whether you can reach a computer across the network.
> [!WARNING] > The DestinationProhibited and DestinationProtocolUnreachable enumeration values have the same numeric value. This is possible because DestinationProhibited applies only to IPv6 and DestinationProtocolUnreachable applies only to IPv4.
## Examples The following code example sends an ICMP echo message and checks the status.
[!code-cs[NclPingSync#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.net.networkinfo_7_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[NclPingSync#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.net.networkinfo_7_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus BadDestination = int32(11018)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination IP address cannot receive ICMP echo requests or should never appear in the destination address field of any IP datagram. For example, calling <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.Send%2A> and specifying IP address "000.0.0.0" returns this status.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus BadHeader = int32(11042)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the header is invalid.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus BadOption = int32(11007)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because it contains an invalid option.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus BadRoute = int32(11012)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because there is no valid route between the source and destination computers.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus DestinationHostUnreachable = int32(11003)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer is not reachable.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus DestinationNetworkUnreachable = int32(11002)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the network that contains the destination computer is not reachable.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus DestinationPortUnreachable = int32(11005)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the port on the destination computer is not available.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus DestinationProhibited = int32(11004)

Docs.summary: The ICMPv6 echo request failed because contact with the destination computer is administratively prohibited. This value applies only to IPv6.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus DestinationProtocolUnreachable = int32(11004)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable, because it does not support the packet's protocol. This value applies only to IPv4. This value is described in IETF RFC 1812 as Communication Administratively Prohibited.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus DestinationScopeMismatch = int32(11045)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the source address and destination address that are specified in an ICMP echo message are not in the same scope. This is typically caused by a router forwarding a packet using an interface that is outside the scope of the source address. Address scopes (link-local, site-local, and global scope) determine where on the network an address is valid.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus DestinationUnreachable = int32(11040)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable; the exact cause of problem is unknown.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus HardwareError = int32(11008)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of a hardware error.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus IcmpError = int32(11044)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of an ICMP protocol error.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus NoResources = int32(11006)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of insufficient network resources.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus PacketTooBig = int32(11009)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet containing the request is larger than the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of a node (router or gateway) located between the source and destination. The MTU defines the maximum size of a transmittable packet.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus ParameterProblem = int32(11015)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because a node (router or gateway) encountered problems while processing the packet header. This is the status if, for example, the header contains invalid field data or an unrecognized option.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus SourceQuench = int32(11016)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was discarded. This occurs when the source computer's output queue has insufficient storage space, or when packets arrive at the destination too quickly to be processed.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus Success = int32(0)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request succeeded; an ICMP echo reply was received. When you get this status code, the other properties contain valid data.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus TimedOut = int32(11010)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo Reply was not received within the allotted time. The default time allowed for replies is 5 seconds. You can change this value using the <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.Send%2A> or <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.SendAsync%2A> methods that take a parameter.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus TimeExceeded = int32(11041)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus TtlExpired = int32(11013)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus TtlReassemblyTimeExceeded = int32(11014)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was divided into fragments for transmission and all of the fragments were not received within the time allotted for reassembly. RFC 2460 (available at www.ietf.org) specifies 60 seconds as the time limit within which all packet fragments must be received.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus Unknown = int32(-1)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed for an unknown reason.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus UnrecognizedNextHeader = int32(11043)

Docs.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the Next Header field does not contain a recognized value. The Next Header field indicates the extension header type (if present) or the protocol above the IP layer, for example, TCP or UDP.
